content:
Would it seem even more keenish if I'd make the game in EGA? I have no plans for it though, and I'm gonna upgrade the current tiles with much more colors. This is just a way to create the tiles for now, as I need more experience with them.

The former option could be the better one.

As for other games, try Pickle Wars, or Prince of Persia 1 and 2.Retodon8

title: Re: Commander Keen in SomeGameName (previous ex-mobilegame)
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Would it seem even more keenish if I'd make the game in EGA? I have no plans for it though, and I'm gonna upgrade the current tiles with much more colors. This is just a way to create the tiles for now, as I need more experience with them.

Do you know any games with high-color graphics that has more complicated tiles than just squares with patterns? I mean this seemingly 3D look. I have seen many games with nice graphics and tiles, but they all were "boring" 2D, and not in isometric view. Maybe they just don't create such games.[hr][/quote]

I'm not suggesting that you need to use only a few colors to make it Keenish. I was referring to the cleanness of line which they possess. They don't try to do too much. That's a nebulous pronouncement, so feel free to ignore it.

I do agree that a whole level of tiles like that would be a little dull. By all means, spiff them up. I didn't mean to suggest that you should limit your tiles to only a few colors.

The most complicated tiles in an isometric game that I can think of are either in Activision's Pitfall remake or in Jazz Jackrabbit II. They're probably the most complicated isometric tiles ever.

It's interesting that games using the isometric platformer view don't usually seem to complex tiles. I wonder why that might be.

When I think of Keenishness I generally think of an environment that I could see a classic 4-6 (or 1-3) Keen in. So that tends to indicate a bright and clear color palette. If you were to make your Keen sprite in a fitting style, a dark and florid environment might be just what the doctor ordered.________________
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v462/lemur821/YorpEye.png[/img]

title: cheers!
content: Looking good!  I'm almost to the point where I get to do this for my own Keen game... ugh.  Yours look fantastic!  Any advice for beginners?  :-)

title: Re: cheers!
content:
It feels nice that you ask for advice from me, but I believe you're much better in tiles then me [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

Maybe one thing that anyone should consider with such tiles as the plank above (or maybe anything else?) is using layers for the different logs at different depth and maybe for anything that has such dimensions. I wish I did.
Creating depth means you have to draw things a bit smaller that are further away, but in isometric fake 3D view this doesn't always work.
I've created a template for the tilesets with every possible tile in it. The template is very simple, the tiles are plain blocks with a different color for every side. When I create a new tile, I start drawing it above the template tile.
For continuous tiles (like the side) I made the first tile, and then copied only the outer 1 pixel box next, above and below it, and drawn the other tiles too. When I had to change a pixel from the original box, I changed it in every other tile too.

I can't think of anything else at the moment, and I feel the things mentioned above were obvious too.

title: Re: !!!
content:
It's not so great if we think about how much time I've already spent on it to become somewhat buggy but all in all I'm proud of my little monster [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] Thank you all for your support, I'm gonna need it in the future too!

I was thinking about making this project open-source but open-source isn't just giving away source code (which I intend to do). It means that I'd have to actually put code and other ideas of other people into my game that may be different from what I've imagined at first. It may make my game better or even known, who knows, but I'd lost much of my independence. This doesn't mean that sometimes I wouldn't accept ideas or even grapics, but open-source is much more than that.

When I can work on my game again I'm gonna fix the bugs I've found in the tileset eg.: some tiles are missing, which won't take long to create, but I'm gonna need to make the steep tiles of the tree branch dropdown-able, so Keen can drop through them. This type of block haven't been implemented in the original games at all that's why I haven't thought of it before. Another must is a type of block where I can set it's steepness not just on one side (top or bottom) but on both at the same time. When all this is ready a new enemy will be born which is gonna need some challenging coding at last and an enemy design too.

Just one question before I go so I can read the answers when I return: do you like the style of the tileset if I leave the tiles as they are? Some of you said about it in an early stage that it doesn't go well with the keen sprite I already have. How about that now? I know I said that I'm gonna make the tiles high-color, but I start to like what I've done. Maybe I can add a few more colors here and there, but that's all I'd do. What do you think? Another option is to make the Keen sprite a bit more "pixelated" with less colors but does it need to change?

title: Cool looking... I bet the full will be better, though. X_X
content:
REVIEW

VIDIO 9/10
The art is awsome! I have to admit, though, Keen's eyes looked a little odd, but that is the only problem in the intire game graphically.

AUDIO 1/10
I couldn't hear any sound from it, but that's because it's a beta. I bet it will have good audio though.

GAME-PLAY 8/10
IT IS AWSOME!!![img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-drool.gif[/img] You jump around collecting points. Unfortinetly, there are no enemies, and there is only one level, but, once again, that's because it's a beta.

STORY 1/10
There isn't a story yet. I'm sure it will have a story soon, though.

OVERALL 19/40=4.75/10
This is a pretty good game. Can't wait for the full![img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-drool.gif[/img] A proud member of the beta testing society

title: Re: This is the best game in the intire world!!
content:
The game looks great Z-1. I'm not dissapointed with the simplified tiles. In fact, their boldness of design actually seems very Keenish to me. They fit with the detailed Keen just fine.

I noticed a little bug on the platform that goes all the way to the left side of the map just above where you start. If you walk left at this edge you start to leave the map and then are transported back to where you started. Perhaps pretending any block off the map is a solid movement stopper would be any easy solution. I think some of the keen maps had extra blocks around the edge of the map that had the "solid" property but the view manager would try not to show. You can see what I mean in keen 6 on the Keens Ship micro level at the start. Pogo jump/pull yourself up into the offscreen hole in the wall on the right of the screen. After you fall down, save the game while you are still offscreen. Now load that game and you will see the hidden blocks. You probably know how to fix your code better than me though [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

I also had something weird happen when trying to jump from the falling platform to the moving one. I think I just touched the moving platform and then Keen sortof floated up and left into blank space like he was riding the platform even though he wasn't! I couldn't replicate it though.

I can hardly wait for the full sized levels!

title: level designer upgrade
content:
I post this to show the difficulties I am facing right now. If you don't care, just skip reading. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v505/z-one/designer.png[/img]
This is how the map designer looks now. The main reason for uploading this image was to show you the new kinds of blocks I had to make in order to be able to create some effects I had in mind. For example there is the "tree" branch which can now be sloped while the player is still able to drop down on it. It works... almost [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-oops.gif[/img] Sometimes Keen just falls through it without reason, when jumping and falling down. This doesn't happen most of the time but it is still frustrating.
Another type of block I have now is the one used on the steep planks. Look at the third block in the list (at the right side of the picture). That block is steep at it's top and at it's bottom side at the same time. Maybe I'm alone with this, but I haven't seen anything like this in other games. It's not a hard thing to create, but it generated some problems I haven't thought of.

I'll start working on an enemy when I have finally managed to work out the problems. It doesn't seem easy though. The whole movement system have to be changed a bit.

Keep at it, and good luck with the floor clipping issues.Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

The development of the hardware, and the greater ability to express every idea that flies into a programmers head, mean that game creators have made the new games congested with every technique in their power. The basic games behind all this are so blurred that people cant catch up. We should go back to basics like Pac-Man and play in an easier, more relaxed way. -Toru Iwatani

title: Re: Oooooh, yeah.
content:
About the steep planks...

I think K5 and 6 are made with basically massive blocks, but Keen 4 is only made of relatively narrow ledges, similar in appearance to the you-can-drop-down-through-these kind, only you can't, and they still block you if you hit them from the bottom, although they don't have a nice bottom edge, because...
They are meant to form a shape, which is filled with background-ish tiles, which usually block, although some are foreground tiles used for hidden passages.
Usually the background-ish tiles are used to fill things up, create some real walls, but in a few levels they're not.
This results in those narrow ledges, also similar to Keen Dreams' wooden log edge thingymabobs all over the place.

Hmmm, I hope that made sense, and I have to add that's how things appeared to me.
I didn't really pick apart the K456 tiles yet, and I'm sure others have.

My point?
I forgot, so I'll just add that I have to admit I also like how things are looking so far; good jorb!Retodon8
You live, you die, you are remembered, you are forgotten. [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Graphics/Keen_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: Re: Oooooh, yeah.
content:
Almost everything works fine now! It was much easier than I thought [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

There's still the problem of what's-wall-and-what's-ground so the game can decide which platform is ready for grabbing. It worked fine with the old blocking tiles, but eg. the plank's edge could be grabbed too and it's not a full block now as it was before. When I only had full blocks and blocks that had one side as a slope, the choice was easy, but now the new kind of blocks should be grabbed too when they have a flat surface, not just the full ones. This is a bit technical and you may not understand this at all, but don't worry, I do! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]

I haven't seen sloped ceilings in Keen 4 even though the tileset contains them, and there's no such thing in Keen 6 either (as far as I remember). Keen 5 had them, but only when there were no need for too narrow walls. I think I have solved my problem, but it may return for some of the enemies, when I have them. If they are too fast or too big my engine may not work correctly, but I still have to try that when the time comes.

title: Re: Oooooh, yeah.
content:
Keen 4's [url=http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/encyclopedia/maps/maps-k4-lvl09.html]Miragia[/url] has glass domes which I think classify as sloped ceilings, if I remember my head-bumping correctly, but you're right, there doesn't seem to be any regular, sloped ceilings.
I would've guessed there were...

As for Keen6, I immediately had to think about [url=http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/encyclopedia/maps/maps-k6-lvl06.html]Bloogton Manufacturing[/url].
There too I think if you jump along the highest part of the ceiling, and try to move along quickly, you sometimes get a bunch of quick head-hitting sounds, because the slopes are in fact slopes to the pixel, as opposed to the Bloogdomes for instance.

Anyway, good luck figuring things out with your slopes!Retodon8

title: Wow...
content:
It is very nice; but what ticked me off was that whenever someone makes a fan game in EGA, they almost always make his shirt red; it is supposed to be pink!!! I really don't mind much, but I still mind it. COuld you change it, or at least tell me why his shirt is red (A good reason; like I made Keen's shirt grey in my mod because that was his sweat-shirt, not because his pink one was in the laundry).

I love the movement feelling... but could you allow the player to choose controls (I swap the up's action with ctrl's, and have since I was a wee lad, and really don't like fan games much, because they make me do it their way).

-- NAJAWA --

title: Re: Wow...
content:
najawa, try using the left side of the keyboard instead of the right, or vice versa.
That way the Ctrl and Alt will have automagically switched places, and I find that whether you have your hands right next to eachother, or spread apart quite a bit doesn't really matter for button pressing, as your brain is the place where your thinking happens, and that's the same either way.

Also I think his shirt is really supposed to be purple, not pink.
I suppose usually the best way to look at it, is to see which of the 2 shades of colour is used the most.
Most palette colours in Keen can be regarded as a darker and a ligher shade of the same thing.
Of course with little sprites, and adding shadows to the darker shades this isn't an exact science.

Also although in some ways I'm conservative, and would prefer a purple/pink shirt as opposed to a red one, thinking up an excuse for an arguably relatively minor colour change to include in the storyline seems a bit... meh.
That's my opinion anyway. Retodon8

title: Re: No updates.
content:
Not that I can talk about actually finishing anything yet, but here's what helps me when I get that sick of working with no results feeling. (And wanting to just go do some other project.) Maybe it can prove useful to you:
Create (write or type) a list of all the things you can think of that need to be finished. Only list the "big" things. For example:
- Draw enemy sprites
- Program enemies
- Draw tiles
- Create levels
- etc.
Now pick from this list what you want to get done first. Break that item down into a more detailed list. Keeping picking an item and breaking it down until you have a list of specific items that you can realistically check at least one item off each time you work on it.
It seems to help to have something I can look at and say "Aha, I'm that far along. Cool, I'm making progress!"

As to the Shikadi effect, yes this would be fantastic. Unfortunately, in the scope of a 2d platfrom game, without using a 3d api (OpenGL for example), it probably isn't realistic. It would be a problem of performance.
A much simplified explanation, if you care:
In a 2d engine, you're typically working with all of your graphics on the video card, as pictures. To put these on the screen, it is a lot like just pressing a peice of paper on the screen. That paper just gets put on top of everything, it doesn't get to take a look at whats behind it. BUT this sort of process is VERY fast.
For the Shikadi effect, you're asking that paper to look at whats behind it. Taking a look at what is behind is a VERY SLOW process. Plus you're changing things based on what is behind. It can be done, but trying to do that along with everything else, at least 30 or 60 times per second is asking quite a lot.
A 3d engine does its drawing in a fundamentally different way. Instead of giving the screen a picture, you tell the video card "here are the shapes that are visible, here's what they are covered with, and here are some distortion formulas that should be applied" and let the video card assemble all of that.
The distortion formulas are the key to the Shikadi effect.

There's nothing wrong with MIDIs - they're still one of the most popular and highest quality ways of creating music on a PC. I mean you could convert them to MP3 if you had to, but you'd still want the MIDI files up until the last minute when you needed to put the song into the game.

title: blarg
content:
Spleen, question for ya: Can MOD files have pitches which are held for more than one measure without re-voicing the pitch? I've tried a few different MIDI-to-MOD conversion utilities over the years, and inevitably multiple measures-long notes are clipped at the bar line.

Any advice?

title: Me a sure.
content:
As in a note lasting for longer than one bar? I'm pretty sure that's possible... bar-lines don't really seem to exist in MOD, just patterns. A note can be held for as long as you want--it's just the length of the sample that affects it, AKAIK, and even that can be worked around with some envelope effects. Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

[url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/]JimSoft Lair[/url]

title: Re: blarg
content: As far as I'm aware, you can't actually turn a note off with MOD files like you can with MIDI.  The only way to stop a note playing is to play another note on the same channel, or in the case of a non-looping sample just wait until the sample has finished playing.

title: Re: Game music
content:
"the MIDI sounds are cheap sounding"

They only sound cheap if you're using something dodgy like the 4MB SoundFont that came with your sound card (or even worse, FM synthesis.) If you have things set up properly, MIDI will sound no worse than anything else.

The advantage I see in it (and other formats like MOD) is that they're fully editable, so it's like making the 'source code' of your composition available - if you get an MP3 it's a lot more work to figure out the notes and/or compose an alternate version of the song.

title: Re: Game music

"the MIDI sounds are cheap sounding"

"They only sound cheap if you're using something dodgy like the 4MB SoundFont that came with your sound card (or even worse, FM synthesis.) If you have things set up properly, MIDI will sound no worse than anything else."

But how many people here have a decent MIDI setup? I do, and presumably you do, but most people don't even know they can swap out the sounds (or can't).

I like the editability, but another advantage is that you can use any GM instrument. You don't have to actually have a tuba lying around.________________

A midi consists of several independednt instruments; you can for example remove that drum, or insert a horn there, whatever.

title: Re: Game music
content:
Whoops, just came back to this topic and I think Mr12000 misunderstood me. Lucky LL was here to explain things [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img] My point was just that if you download a game with MP3 music your only choice is to listen to the MP3s. If you download a game with MIDI, MOD, IMF, etc. music - generally anything that stores the actual notes in the song then it's much easier for someone to find out what those notes are, if they want to e.g. learn to play the tune on a piano, make a remix of your song, etc.

Like Naj says, MP3 "keeps people from screwing your masterpiece" but IMKO having people create remixes and things is half the fun - we all like the remixes of the Keen music, right? They would've been a lot harder to create if the Keen music was MP3, WAV, OGG, etc.

Personally I think the best format for a game would be one of the MOD formats (S3M, XM, IT, etc.) These combine the "niceness" of having the notes available for people who are interested, yet you get to include your own tiny software synth to play the songs, so they're guaranteed to sound the same on any PC. Plus 300-500kB/song is a lot smaller than an MP3 of comparable quality.

title: Keep is small, stupid.
content:
It's not only the download speed I take into account when it comes to the size of a game, but the drive space it takes up. I use and sell alot of older computers customised to run games like this, and storage is always at a premium.

I would rather the game include MOD by default and have an optional addon available for those who want to use MP3s instead or wish to listen to the soundtrack on an MP3 player. That way, both those who have bandwidth and HDD space to burn and others who prefer a small download are catered for.

Mr12000's point about music quality is null and void. There is no difference in quality between MOD and MP3, it's just that MP3 is far more standard than MOD. Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

title: Re: Keep is small, stupid.
content:
The only problem with going down the IMF track like Keen is that unless you're writing a native DOS game, it's pretty difficult to play IMF files. You have to include a software synth, and unlike MOD files an OPL synthesiser takes up a *lot* of CPU cycles - you can play MOD files on an XT computer (which can barely run Keen itself) whereas you pretty much need a 300+MHz CPU to play IMFs without a hardware synthesiser.

In theory you could create a MOD file that sounds close to an IMF, but it probably wouldn't be worth the trouble - there's a reason why people here are always trying to convert the IMFs into MIDIs... [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: A name!
content:
Not supporting means they don't respond to support requests regarding the functions. But if you know their self-imposed rules regarding COM (which in turn governs DirectX), you know that updating a component means changing, fixing and adding features. However, it can't break existing features. So DirectX 10 still supports all the features of DirectX 1.

To get to older implementations of particular methods (functions), you need to be explicit in what version you want. However, in the case of DirectDraw functions, there are no new functions, so the old are used and there's no need to "be explicit."
Now what I don't know about is what happens if you use a later DirectX SDK and compile using features only available in previous versions. (It should work, but you may need to add flags to tell the compiler exactly what you're doing.)
In my case, I'm using the DirectX 7 SDK (the last one with DirectDraw). But don't get too worried. I have DirectX 9 installed so I can play new games. The SDK is only used by the compiler. Don't know how hard it is to get older SDK's, so if you need a copy, let me know and I'll put one up. (If I recall correctly, it's around 200mb, so you'll want a fast connection to download it.)

My appologies if they've actually stated they are eliminating DirectDraw features. Please point me to the source of this, since it concerns me greatly.

Finally, in a level editor, I'm sure it's unnecessary, but using Direct3d to do 2d stuff provides a lot of cool graphical features, and it's not too complicated of a technological leap. (In fact, you can just build your own backend system to hide the fact that it's actually 3d and just pretend you're working with 2d objects.)

title: Re: A name!
content:
"I've never used DirectX and haven't programmed anything 3D before and I'm not about to start learning something hard now."

In that case I'd strongly recommend using OpenGL instead - DirectX (at least from a low level C++ point of view) requires a lot of mucking around with classes and it can be *very* complicated, whereas OpenGL is more or less a bunch of function calls, so if you're new to 3D programming you'll quite likely find OpenGL easier to learn with.

Plus OpenGL runs under Linux as well [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]

title: Re: A name!
content: I'll consider it when I want to learn 3D, but should a hardware accelerated 3D graphics card really be necessary for a 2D map editor? I don't think so...[hr]The human brain is not user-friendly...

title: Re: A name!
content:
Don't forget that OpenGL and DirectX both default back to software renderers if you don't have a hardware accelerated card (but who doesn't these days?) and if you do have a 3D card you can easily get nifty 3D effects like semitransparency by using only the 2D capabilities of the card.

I'm considering making my 2D map editor OpenGL based, simply because it'll save me the effort of coding transparency blending, it'll make animation simpler (just switch textures and refresh), and it should make scrolling *really* smooth.

title: Re: creating a keen 4-6 editor
content:
Well, I didnt do anything with Ted till now but I've debugged many parts of the K4-Engine and know, how it works... If u want to have the piece of code I can send it to u...

For short:

If u press the up-key, the engine calls a function to check wether there is a switch or a door... if there's a switch||door keen needs first to slide to reach the correct position.

After that the corresponding action is called...

If it is a door the engine takes a look at the info layer and set's keen to the target-coordinates stores there (0x1234: 0x12 where the x-coords and 0x34 are the y-coords)

If it is a switch the engine takes the target-coords of the info-layer from the switch and checks if at the target position the info layer contains the value 0x000F. If so then there's a bridge - if not, it's blocker tile...

if it's a blocker-tile then the foreground-tile is just XORed with 0x001F.

if it's a bridge the following piece of code is executed...
[pre] for( word curY=newY; curY < (newY+2); curY++ ) { word offset = map_line_start[ curY ] + newX; /* loc_1614, loc_1615, loc_1616 */ word *tile_pointer = maplayer[1] + offset + (curY != newY); /* loc_1617, loc_1618 */ startX = newX (curY != newY); /* loc_1620 */ for( word curX = startX; curX < level_width; curX++ ) { foreground_tile_2 = *tile_pointer++; short delta_tile = p_maphead[3942+foreground_tile_2];/* tile_fg_animlist[BX] */ if( delta_tile == 0 ) /* nothing to change */ break; /* next run in outer for-loop */ foreground_tile_2 += delta_tile; sub_490( &foreground_tile_2, 1, curX, curY, 1, 1 ); /* change tile */ }}[/pre]
(my interpretation of the asm-output)
sub_490 changes a tile in the maplayer and refreshes the output to the screen...

I hope this helps a little bit...

MfG

[hr]

Hi again

ok, I'm unsure if u already know the format of the map-files, but if u need some info's here whe go...

The engine normale uses two files for the maps: "maphead.???" and "gamemaps.???" where "maphead.???" just contains 100 offsets (datatype: long, 4byte) for the level-header's in "gamemaps.???"

struct of levelheader:
[pre] struct mapheader { Sint32 layer_offsets[3]; Uint16 layer_length[3]; Uint16 width, height; char lvlName[16]; /* ted-level-name, not shown in game*/ char sign[4]; /* signature: "!ID! */}[/pre]

layer[0] is the background-layer (only not maskable tiles)
layer[1] is the foreground-layer (only maskable tiles)
layer[3] is the info-layer (the first of the maskabel tiles, contains enemys and some infos like target for doors and so on...)

every layer_offset[] points to the place, where a layer is stored... each layer is compressed twice: first u have to uncarmacize them and after that u have to unRLE them.
the first two bytes contain the 'uncaramacized' length of the plane and after 'uncarmacizing' the first two bytes contain the 'unRLEed' size (which has to be width*length . That should be all for the moment... if u need help with a carmacize/decarmacize algorithem: just ask

MfG (again

title: Re: creating a keen 4-6 editor
content:
1. No idea..

2. The actual level data is in GAMEMAPS.CKx. The header data (called MAPHEAD) is stored in the exe, and thus needs to be patched. With big patches like this, the patch can be just a binary file that is read with a specific patch command. MAPHEAD tells the level data offset of GAMEMAPS; where the level data starts there.Eat your veggies!
